awd_titl_txt: Cyberlearning: Detecting and Predicting Procrastination in Online and Social Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
As online education becomes increasingly available and trusted by both employers and students, many workers are turning to online courses to advance their education and job prospects.  However, online courses demand effective time management skills, as students are required to plan and set goals, manage their time, and work by themselves (or in a group), often with less structure than an in-person course.  This increases the risks of procrastination, a key challenge to time management and success in both work and education contexts.  To address those risks, this project will use computational algorithms to model students' procrastination behaviors, identify indicators of likely future procrastination, and detect it early on in both individual and in group work.  The algorithms will learn to predict procrastination according to learners' studying behavior captured by a time management application and their performance in courses. The findings of this project can be used to enhance students' learning by helping them to set goals and plan their work, monitor their progress, and keep track of what they need to do to successfully accomplish their assignments on time.  These findings can be applied to related areas such as workforce development, and the data collection tools and algorithms developed will be made available to other researchers who want to work on related questions at the intersection of behavior and learning.

This project examines individual and group procrastination behavior by developing computational models using data on students' self-reported cognitive, metacognitive, motivational, and affective processes. Current theories of procrastination will be studied and extended based on cross-sectional self-report survey data asking for student self-ratings of procrastination related to academic tasks, and time-stamped trace data of studying and interaction behavior generated by a mobile app used by students during their courses. The cyberlearning advancements of this study are (1) a novel model of individual and individual-in-group (social) procrastination, to detect procrastination based on both self-report and trace data; (2) a novel model to predict student performance based on their procrastination, previous task accomplishment behavior, and previous performance; and (3) exploration of the most parsimonious combination of self-report and trace data to produce effective procrastination model. These goals will be accomplished by (a) developing and updating an application for data collection and survey administration, (b) deploying the app in several graduate online courses, (c) analyzing data to understand underlying procrastination processes, and (d) developing machine learning algorithms to model and detect procrastination. The project will result in the dissemination of findings and developed algorithms to the broader field of sequential data science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Academic procrastination is defined as the voluntary and irrational delay of action on academic tasks, despite expecting to be worse off because of the delay. Procrastination is widespread among students, with 50-75% reporting engaging in this delaying behavior to varying extents. Academic procrastination can have negative effects on learning outcomes, like grades and class performance, and also on one’s mental health, through negative emotions associated with this behavior, such as anxiety. 

The first step in helping students reduce procrastination is to examine and understand how and under what circumstances students procrastinate and how we can use computational algorithms to model this behavior and identify and detect patterns of studying behaviors (in both individual and group work) that can be characterized as procrastination. 

To reach this goal, our team has developed a mobile app, called Proccoli, to help students plan and set goals (e.g., exams, assignments), break their big goals down into more manageable chunks (i.e., subgoals), keep track of their studying by using a timer in the app (according to Pomodoro method), and monitor their progress by looking at charts in the app that summarize their studying sessions into easy-to-understand graphs. Besides using the app, our research participants took several questionnaires that measured their procrastination tendencies, self-regulation, and motivation, among other factors. 

Several hundred students at the University at Albany, SUNY, have used Proccoli in the past couple of years, and we have analyzed their studying data to better understand procrastinatory behavior. 

By analyzing the large amount of data gathered by Proccoli and our questionnaires we have found interesting results. As examples of our findings, We modeled student activities with Hawkes processes and discovered that: (1) the student behavioral dynamics could be bursty and irregular, with more burstiness in students with procrastinatory behaviors, (2) students with less procrastinatory behaviors have more follow-up activities for a longer time after starting to work on a goal,  and (3) students who focus more on performance comparison with others show more procrastinatory behaviors. Furthermore, (4) We developed a “formula” that takes into account several variables (e.g., when students started working on their goal, the date of their deadline, how many times and for how long they worked on their goal, etc.) to measure how much they procrastinated. How this formula measured procrastination levels was related to how established questionnaires measured procrastination. (5) We also found that ADHD was related to higher chronic, academic, and decisional procrastination, with no difference between male and female students. (6) Students who had higher academic procrastination were lacking in critical self-regulated learning skills, such as effective planning and goal setting, selecting a suitable place and time for studying, managing their study time, and monitoring their learning. On the other hand, procrastination (academic and decisional) was linked to fear of failure, and lack of motivation as well. 

In addition to the data collected by Proccoli, we leveraged large-scale public datasets of student activities to study and detect procrastination on a broader scale. We developed various machine learning models and algorithms to achieve the following: (1) accurately predict students' time-to-study; (2) group students into clusters based on their procrastination behaviors (3) analyze the impact of regularity and external factors, such as deadlines, on procrastination; (4) integrate models of student knowledge with their procrastination tendencies; and (4) predict students' future performance while accounting for their procrastination patterns.

We have presented our findings at several national and international conferences to scholars in the field and have published them in peer-reviewed proceedings. The data collection tools and algorithms developed have been made available for free to other researchers who want to work on related questions at the intersection of behavior and learning.

This project contributed substantially to the education of graduate and undergraduate students and the training of a technically qualified workforce. Two doctoral students in Computer Science and one undergraduate student in Computer Science received training during this project. An additional three doctoral students in Education and one undergraduate student in Psychology received training, contributing to the development of a highly qualified workforce. Two doctoral dissertations were completed and defended by our doctoral students, and the Undergraduate student in Computer Science completed an Honors Thesis as a result of their work on this project.
